content: The legal philosophy of Judge Sonia Sotomayor will be closely examined during her confirmation hearing for the Supreme Court, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee said this morning. But he added that he doubted that a filibuster would be attempted to block the nomination. "We'll have to go back and look at the record and see what most people felt. I believe she's entitled to a fair slate now, a clean slate, a fresh start to examine the entire record in context and give her a chance to explain that," the senator said. "There are troubling things that are going to have to be inquired into." Despite GOP concerns about whether Sotomayor is an activist, or her positions on such wedge issues as racial preference in the workplace and abortion, Democrats control Congress. In the Senate, Democrats have 59 seats and a 60th expected when Al Franken's legal case is resolved in Minnesota. "http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-sotomayor-senate28-2009may28,0,6326072.story" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

title: No filibuster in the works for Sonia Sotomayor...but still questions to be answered.

content: Her statement: I would hope that a wise Latina woman with the richness of her experiences would more often than not reach a better conclusion than a white male who hasn't lived that life. Since when is bringing personal prejudices to a judgmental decision considered right for a Federal Judge??? If that does not show a racist frame of mind in a written speech, then what does? Isn't the proper frame of mind of justice supposed to be blind to race creed and color, only looking to the Law? What if a white nominee had said something just the opposite - would that not be racist? What if Sotomayor had said "black man"??? Would she still be Obama's choice??? Racism is racism, no matter who spouts it and no matter what context it is in... Wandering and Wondering

content: If she were conservative she would have been given the "Bork" treatment.
reply: If she were conservative she would have been given the "Bork" treatment.
title: No filibuster in the works for Sonia Sotomayor...but still questions to be answered.

content: Sonia Sotomayor + empathy = bad President Barack Obama: May 1, 2009 "I will seek someone who understands that justice isn't about some abstract legal theory or footnote in a casebook, it is also about how are laws effect the daily realities of peoples lives.... I view that quality of empathy , of understanding and identifying with peoples' hopes and struggles, as an essential ingredient for arriving at just decisions and outcomes." Clarence Thomas + empathy = good President George H.W. Bush: July 1, 1991 "I have followed this man's career for some time, and he has excelled in everything that he has attempted. He is a delightful and warm, intelligent person who has great empathy and a wonderful sense of humor" Emphasis mine More hypocrisy from the right. It never ends. Eric Allie, <Caglecartoons.com> A great take on the Sotomayor nomination.

content: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: Her statement: I would hope that a wise Latina woman with the richness of her experiences would more often than not reach a better conclusion than a white male who hasn't lived that life. Since when is bringing personal prejudices to a judgmental decision considered right for a Federal Judge??? If that does not show a racist frame of mind in a written speech, then what does? Isn't the proper frame of mind of justice supposed to be blind to race creed and color, only looking to the Law? What if a white nominee had said something just the opposite - would that not be racist? What if Sotomayor had said "black man"??? Would she still be Obama's choice??? Racism is racism, no matter who spouts it and no matter what context it is in... When Justice Clarence Thomas opined during his conformation hearings that "I believe ... that I can make a contribution, that I can bring something different to the court, that I can walk in the shoes of the people who are affected by what the court does." How is what he says any different than Sotomayor pointing out that her experience as a Latina brings 'something different that allows her to walk in the shoes of the people who are affected by what the court does." Everyone 'wants' justice to be blind to race, creed and color. Well guess what, that statue that stands in front of the Supreme Court building is just that, a statue. A depiction of an ideal that is carved in stone. The people on the Supreme Court who strive to give 'JUSTICE' meaning are human and thus have all the weaknesses that flesh, blood, and emotion bring into the equation. How can twisting the context or the gender to suit a particular belief add anything to the discussion, other than to try and justify that which is already fixed in the mind. IMHO if President Obama nominated Mother Theresa, were she still alive and an American, to the Supreme Court; it would not make any difference because the opposition have made their minds up to be against the selection no matter who it is. That's just politics I guess, and as the saying goes, 'elections matter'.

A depiction of an ideal that is carved in stone. The people on the Supreme Court who strive to give 'JUSTICE' meaning are human and thus have all the weaknesses that flesh, blood, and emotion bring into the equation. How can twisting the context or the gender to suit a particular belief add anything to the discussion, other than to try and justify that which is already fixed in the mind. content: quote: I'm tired of these people acting like they won the election. Somebody needs to stand up and say, "When you win the election, you pick the nominees. Until then, shut up! Just shut up! Just go away! Bury yourselves in your rat holes and don't come out until you win an election. When you win an election, you can put all these wackos all over the court, but until then, SHUT UP! You are really irritating me." Rush Limbaugh, July 5, 2005

content: quote: How is what he says any different than Sotomayor pointing out that her experience as a Latina brings 'something different that allows her to walk in the shoes of the people who are affected by what the court does." Because she used the word "better". That single word in her statement makes her sound as if only those like her can save America. Her experience is greater than anyone else's. She can pass judgement on any subject where other's only have limited experience and can't reach conclusions she can.
